message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound shows a single, small, benign-appearing ovarian mass, without any signs of malignancy or risk factors, therefore a follow-up examination is the most appropriate next step. Diagnostic laparoscopy is invasive and usually a last resort. CA-125 level is not specific enough for ovarian cancer diagnosis. Oral contraceptive can be used to treat ovarian cysts, but it's not necessary for a small, benign-appearing mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a single, small, and benign-looking mass in the ovary, which suggests it is likely a functional cyst. Therefore, a follow-up examination is the most appropriate next step in management. Diagnostic laparoscopy is an invasive option that is not necessary at this point. CA-125 level is not indicated for a simple ovarian cyst. Oral contraceptive is an option to prevent future cysts, but it is not necessary for the current situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This patient has a small, likely benign ovarian mass and is asymptomatic. The next step would be to observe and repeat the ultrasound in a few months to see if there are any changes in size or appearance. Diagnostic laparoscopy would be invasive and unnecessary at this point. CA-125 level is elevated in some ovarian cancers but can also be elevated in benign conditions. Oral contraceptives may help prevent future ovarian cysts or masses but should not be used to directly manage an existing mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound shows a simple ovarian cyst which is a common finding in reproductive age women and is usually benign. The patient does not have any symptoms of malignancy such as ascites or abnormal CA-125 levels. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is a follow-up examination to monitor the size of the cyst and look for any changes over time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mass characteristics on the ultrasound suggest a benign ovarian cyst, and therefore a follow-up examination is the most appropriate next step in management. Surgical intervention is not necessary in most cases of benign ovarian cysts. CA-125 level and oral contraceptive therapy are not indicated in this scenario. Diagnostic laparoscopy may be necessary if there is evidence of malignancy or if the cyst is causing significant symptoms or growth.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound findings suggest a simple ovarian cyst, which is a common finding in young women and rarely malignant. Follow-up with a repeat ultrasound in 4 to 6 weeks is the most appropriate next step to monitor the cyst and ensure it resolves on its own. Diagnostic laparoscopy may be necessary if the cyst persists or increases in size. CA-125 level is not appropriate in this case because it is not sensitive or specific for ovarian malignancy. Oral contraceptive may be considered to prevent future cyst formation, but it is not necessary for the management of this particular cyst.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a small, simple ovarian cyst without significant signs of malignancy. Follow-up examination is appropriate for simple ovarian cysts less than 5 cm in diameter as they are usually functional and tend to resolve on their own within a few menstrual cycles. Diagnostic laparoscopy is not indicated at this time. CA-125 levels may be helpful in evaluating ovarian masses, but they are not specific enough to distinguish between benign and malignant tumors. Oral contraceptives may help prevent the formation of new ovarian cysts, but they are not appropriate as a management strategy for this particular mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The smooth and mobile adnexal mass with no signs of blood flow or septae suggest a simple ovarian cyst, which is common and often resolves on its own. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to follow-up with a repeat pelvic examination and ultrasound in 4-6 weeks to see if the cyst has resolved or changed in size. However, if the cyst persists or grows, further management options such as laparoscopy or CA-125 level may be considered. Oral contraceptive can also be used as a management option for asymptomatic simple ovarian cysts, but it’s not the most appropriate next step in this case.

We refer to a medical source for help. The ultrasound findings suggest a simple ovarian cyst, which is a common finding in young women and is usually self-limited. Therefore, follow-up examination is the most appropriate next step in management. Diagnostic laparoscopy and CA-125 level are not necessary at this time. Oral contraceptives may be an option if the cyst persists or if the patient has recurrent cysts.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ultrasound shows a simple ovarian cyst, which is commonly seen in young women and usually benign. Follow-up examination with repeat ultrasound in 8-12 weeks is appropriate to ensure that the cyst has not increased in size, which could suggest malignancy. Diagnostic laparoscopy is too invasive at this stage, and CA-125 is not indicated as it is not a sensitive marker for early ovarian cancer. Oral contraceptives may help prevent the formation of new cysts but are not indicated in the management of this existing simple cyst.
